slides.title: Introduction to Premium Audits
slides.notes: Introduction to the concept of premium audits, a critical aspect of PolicyCenter.
slides.narration: Welcome to our exploration of premium audits within Guidewire PolicyCenter. Premium audits play a vital role in ensuring that the premiums charged to policyholders accurately reflect the actual risk exposure over a policy term. In this lesson, we'll dive into how audits are configured, executed, and managed, setting the stage for accurate billing and compliance with regulatory requirements. Let's get started by understanding what makes premium audits unique in the insurance lifecycle.
slides.ocrText: Premium Audits

slides.title: Understanding Audit Types
slides.notes: Overview of the different types of premium audits used in PolicyCenter.
slides.narration: In PolicyCenter, it's crucial to distinguish between various audit types. We have final audits, which occur at the end of a policy term, and premium reports, which can happen periodically within the term. Each type serves a different purpose and is triggered by specific conditions and schedules. Understanding these distinctions helps in configuring audits that align with both business needs and regulatory standards.

slides.title: Audit Methods Overview
slides.notes: Examine the methods used to conduct premium audits.
slides.narration: When conducting premium audits, insurers can choose from methods like physical, phone, estimated, or voluntary audits. These methods allow flexibility based on the resources available and the nature of the insured's business. For instance, physical audits are thorough but resource-intensive, while voluntary audits rely on the policyholder's input. This flexibility ensures audits can be tailored to the specific circumstances and requirements of each policy.

slides.title: Characteristics of Audits
slides.originalNotes:
Audits
Audits are unlike other transactions for the following reasons:
Audits utilize the policy information and are tied to the policy periods, but they cannot alter the policy contract-
Audits don't have an associated edit effective date and do not get 'issued".
They can be executed at any time within the policy term. (The only other job which typically executes on a recurring basis is a renewal, and that technically occurs only once per term.)
They are initiated and are viewable in a separate place in the Policy Center interface.

In the case of workers’ compensation LOB, the premium is typically based on the payroll of the insured workers. It cannot be predicted how many workers will be employed during the policy term or their salaries-Consequently, the payroll is estimated. Therefore, an audit is required to convert estimated amounts to actual data which in turn is reflected on the policy premium. Occasionally, an LOB which does not appear to be based on estimates may be subject to a Final Audit (i.e., Business Auto). Final Audits or other audit 'reporting' can be applied to several LOBs.

Premium Reports are available for workers’ compensation LOBs. Final Audits are available for worker's compensation and general liability LOBs- Premium Reports: Premium reports are an audit subtype that are created for interim periods within a policy term. Premium reporting audits adjust estimated data, such as payroll, inventory, and construction reports. The primary distinction between the two types of activities is that an "audit" is executed by the insurer whereas a •premium report" is prepared exclusively by the policyholder (or their representative) and are not typically verified by the insurer. A premium report or a final audit is created using any of the available audit methods (voluntary, phone,  physical or estimate)-

slides.title: Types of Premium Audits
slides.originalNotes:
Audit types
A final audit is a type of premium audit. There is only one final audit; it is run at the end of a policy term. Premium reports, a secondary audit, may take place at regular intervals during the policy term depending on the user's audit configuration schedule.

This distinction matters because it affects when and how adjustments to premiums are made, impacting both cash flow and accounting practices for insurers and insureds alike.

slides.title: Methods of Conducting Premium Audits
slides.originalNotes:
Premium audit methods
Physical: A representative (i.e. premium auditor) makes an in person visit to the policyholder to review business records, verify,  and obtain required audit information.
Phone: The auditor contacts the policyholder by phone to obtain audit information.
Estimated: Used when other methods are unavailable (i.e., policyholder went out of business, or records were lost).
Voluntary: The insurer distributes a form to the policyholder requesting audit information. The policyholder completes and returns the form for processing.

slides.title: Scheduling and Managing Audits
slides.originalNotes:
Premium audit process
When the policy is issued, PolicyCenter adds scheduled audit items to the policy. These audits can be viewed by clicking the Audit Schedule link in the policy file. These are not actual audit jobs, they are a list of the anticipated, uninitialized audit jobs for the policy period sorted by their start and end dates; their status is Scheduled. When a policy is canceled or reinstated, PolicyCenter revises the number of scheduled audits according to the coverage dates. Each of the scheduled items includes a process start date, an audit method and a due date. Users with the proper permissions canedit these fields before the audit job is initialized.

slides.title: Executing the Audit Process
slides.originalNotes:
Audit process
An Audit Task is a regularly scheduled batch process that starts the audit jobs on its process start date. The Process Start Date is set according to the audit schedule(s) configured in Product Designer.

The Audit Method dictates how many days before the End Date each audit should be started. Note: Physical audits start approximately a month before the period end. With the correct permissions, a user may Stan an audit prior to the Process Stad Date using the Start button on the audit schedule item. Once the process starts, the audit status changes from Scheduled to In Progress. The audit becomes a draft policy transaction, and the scheduled item becomes a link to the audit wizard. The user can enter the audit information.

Enter the audit details into the Audit Summary and Audit Details screens. Premiums are determined by clicking the Calculate Premiums button. Finalize the calculations by clicking the Submit button. At that time, the audit becomes non- editable, the status becomes Completed, and the audit schedule displays the resulting premiums. The user can change completed audits.

slides.title: Final Audits in Detail
slides.notes: Deep dive into final audits and their significance.
slides.narration: Final audits play a critical role in reconciling estimated premiums with actual figures at the end of a policy term. They ensure that the ultimate cost reflects true exposure, which is essential for accurate billing and regulatory compliance. PolicyCenter's base configuration supports final audits for workers' compensation and general liability, but it can be customized for other lines of business as needed.

slides.title: Understanding Final Audits
slides.originalNotes:
Final audit
Final audits:
Cover the entire policy term
One final audit is conducted each policy term
Available in PolicyCenter base configuration for workers' compensation and general liability

A final audit contains the verified, ultimate cost for a variable basis policy- Final audits are important in determining actual policy premiums. When the policy is issued, the estimated annual premium (EAP) is based on the policyholder's estimated basis for the entire policy year- The final audit is conducted at expiration or cancellation. An auditor reviews the policyholder’s records and the actual payroll amounts (submitted by the policyholder) for the past policy term. The cost of the policy is recalculated using the actual basis amount and the policyholder is billed or refunded the difference.

Insurers must also report final audit information to regulatory agencies- Worker’s compensation unit statistical reports (unit stat reports) are sent to state bureaus or councils that handle multiple states (that is, NCCI). Unit stat reports are used by the state to calculate policyholder experience modifications and suggested or mandatory rates obtained by the insurer- PolicyCenter does not create or send unit stat reports. However, PolicyCenter can be configured to export final audit data for statistical reporting. This data can be imported into another system,  such as the unit stat software application used by a particular state.

slides.title: Steps for Conducting Final Audits
slides.originalNotes:
Final audit general steps
PolicyCenter initially schedules a final audit when a submission, rewrite, or renewal job is issued. The line of business and choices on the Payment page determine whether a final audit is required and a choice of audit schedules. Other jobs, such as policy change, reinstatement, or cancellation can affect the audit.  The batch process audit task uses the audit start date to determine when an audit begins.  If the user selects to audit the policy, the audit is completed by one of the audit methods: physical, phone, voluntary or estimation

If the user chose to waive the audit, then the audit status changes to complete, however,  an audit can be manually restored to the schedule. The slide diagram shows the steps needed to conduct a final audit.  These steps are for the default configuration of PolicyCenter.  Insurers' business requirements
can also alter the process.

slides.title: Revising Final Audits
slides.notes: Process for revising a completed final audit.
slides.narration: Revising a final audit involves withdrawing the original audit and creating a new one to incorporate changes. This ensures that any updates are accurately reflected in the policy's financials. PolicyCenter handles this process seamlessly, notifying the billing system of reversals and updates, which maintains consistency across systems and reduces the risk of billing errors.

slides.title: Revising Completed Audits
slides.originalNotes:
Revising final audit
If changes to a completed final audit are needed, it can be revised. Revising a Final Audit withdraws the original audit, so the new audit can incorporate changes made by another job. PolicyCenter notifies the billing system that the first audit is reversed and will be replaced by a new audit. The new final audit is created automatically when the previous version is revised.

It's a critical part of handling dynamic business environments where changes are inevitable.

Adding a new Premium Report
Similar to revising a final audit, a premium report can be reversed, however, it does not create a new premium report after it is reversed. A user must explicitly add the premium report and process it.

Policy Center lets you add a premium report to a policy for any unreported portion of a policy period. A premium report may be added to a policy in the following example cases:
The policy originally had eleven ( 11) monthly reports plus a final audit The underwriter wants to add a 12th report instead of waiting for the final audit to collect the final month's premium.
A user submits a policy change on a policy with one or more completed reports.  These reports must be reversed and added. 
The user waived a period and wants to add it again.
